en_first_half: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the
en_second_half: Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (Mem., I must ask the Count all about them.)

Tôi sẽ nghỉ lại cùng những người Szekely. Nghe nói họ xuất thân từ Attila và là hậu duệ của người Hung nô. Có lẽ điều này là có thật bởi vì vào thế kỷ thứ mười hai, khi người Magyard đi chinh phục xứ

Dường như mọi mê tín dị đoan trên thế giới đều có ở vùng Carpates, và tất cả luôn làm khuấy động trí tưởng tượng của dân gian. Nếu thực tế đúng là như vậy, thì những ngày nghỉ lại xứ này của tôi chắc sẽ rất thú vị. (Chắc chắn tôi sẽ luôn quấy rầy ngài bá tước với những câu hỏi về cái tín ngưỡng dị đoan này).

Voy entre estos últimos, que aseguran ser descendientes de Atila y los hunos. Esto puede ser cierto, puesto que cuando los magiares conquistaron el país,
es_second_half: en el siglo XI, encontraron a los hunos, que ya se habían establecido en él. Leo que todas las supersticiones conocidas en el mundo están reunidas en la herradura de los Cárpatos, como si fuese el centro de alguna especie de remolino imaginativo; si es así, mi estancia puede ser muy interesante. (Recordar que debo preguntarle al conde acerca de esas supersticiones).

en_first_half: 4 May.—I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened
en_second_half: sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.

Hai vợ chồng ông chủ nhìn nhau vẻ lo lắng rồi quay sang ấp úng

Khi tôi hỏi về bá tước Dracula và tòa lâu đài của ông ta, cả hai vợ chồng cùng làm dấu thánh và trả lời họ hoàn toàn không rõ gì hết, rồi ra hiệu cho tôi hiểu họ không muốn nói về chuyện đó nữa. Vì giờ lên đường đã tới nên tôi không còn thời gian để hỏi thăm qua những người khác. Tôi thấy sự việc thật bí ẩn và không có sức thuyết phục.

en_results: his face turned pale, and he dropped into a chair, his hands trembling violently. "This is most serious," he muttered,

We must gather more information and perhaps seek the counsel of the authorities to protect him. Time is of the essence, and I propose we meet with Mr. Hawkins immediately to discuss our next steps. His life may depend on our prompt action."

Al oír el nombre del llamante, su expresión cambió; se levantó con determinación, preparándose para enfrentar lo que venía. "Hasta luego, señor", murmuró, dejando la carta y la bolsa en la mesa, mientras salió de la habitación, dejando tras de sí una atmósfera de incertidumbre y preguntas sin respuestas.

en_first_half: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thought—that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence. How was it that all the
en_second_half: people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it. In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me to understand. To-night he may talk of himself, if I turn the conversation that way. I must be very careful, however, not to awake his suspicion.
en_results: next day, I resolved to observe him more closely. The Count's behavior was peculiar; he seemed to move with a purpose, always busy, yet there was an air of mystery about him that was unsettling. He would often pause, as if listening to unheard voices, and then proceed with his tasks with renewed vigor. This observation only deepened my unease. As the sun began to set, casting long shadows across the castle's corridors, I noticed the Count's demeanor change. He appeared more agitated, glancing frequently towards the windows as if expecting someone. This behavior puzzled me, and I wondered if he was indeed alone in the castle or if there were others hidden from my sight. The thought of being watched, even hunted, within these very walls sent shivers down my spine. en_results_raw: next day, I resolved to observe him more closely. The Count's behavior was peculiar; he seemed to move with a purpose, always busy, yet there was an air of mystery about him that was unsettling. He would often pause, as if listening to unheard voices, and then proceed with his tasks with renewed vigor. This observation only deepened my unease. As the sun began to set, casting long shadows across the castle's corridors, I noticed the Count's demeanor change. He appeared more agitated, glancing frequently towards the windows as if expecting someone. This behavior puzzled me, and I wondered if he was indeed alone in the castle or if there were others hidden from my sight. The thought of being watched, even hunted, within these very walls sent shivers down my spine. That night, I decided to explore the castle further, hoping to uncover the truth behind the Count's enigmatic presence and the strange occurrences I had witnessed. My investigation led me to the basement, a place untouched by daylight and filled with an oppressive silence. As I ventured deeper, I stumbled upon a room I had not seen before. The air was thick with dust, and the walls were lined with ancient books and strange artifacts. In the center of the room stood a large, ornate box, its surface covered in intricate carvings that seemed to move in the dim light. My heart raced as I approached it, unsure of what I might find. As I reached out to touch the box, a soft click echoed through the room, and the lid slowly creaked open. Inside, I discovered a collection of vials, each containing a different liquid, some clear, others dark and swirling. Next to them lay a small, leather-bound book, its pages filled with notes and diagrams. The sight before me was both fascinating and terrifying. These were not ordinary potions or remedies; they were something far more potent, possibly capable of controlling the very essence of life and death. The realization dawned on me that the Count was not merely a man, but a sorcerer of immense power, using his magic to manipulate the wolves and control the events that led me to this forsaken place. The question now was, what was his ultimate goal, and how could I, a mere visitor, survive in a castle haunted by dark magic and a sorcerer's will? My mind raced with possibilities, each more horrifying than the last. I knew I had to act quickly, to find a way to escape or, at the very least, to outwit the Count and his supernatural abilities. As I closed the box and backed away, I could feel the weight of the castle pressing down on me, the walls closing in with every step I took towards the safety of my room. The night was long, filled with restless sleep and nightmares of shadowy figures and glowing eyes. When dawn finally broke, I knew I had to confront the Count, to demand answers and, if possible, to find a way to break the spell that held the castle in its grip. The day ahead promised to be fraught with danger, but I had no choice. The fate of my life depended on my courage and my wits. As I prepared myself for what was to come, I clung to a sliver of hope that somewhere, somehow, I could turn the tide against the sorcerer and his dark powers.
vi_first_half: Đang mải suy nghĩ, tôi chợt nghe thấy có tiếng khép cửa phía dưới: lão bá tước đã về. Lão không đi ngay vào thư viện. Tôi phải rón rén trở về phòng mình. en_first_half: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted, and she was breathing—not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and
en_second_half: more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was. Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not. However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.

es_first_half: Cuando me incliné sobre ella pude ver que todavía dormía. Sus labios estaban abiertos, y ella estaba respirando, pero no con la suavidad acostumbrada sino a grandes y pesadas boqueadas, como si tratara de llenar plenamente sus pulmones a cada respiro. Al acercarme, subió la mano y tiró del cuello de su camisón de dormir, como si sintiera frío. Sin embargo, siguió dormida. Yo puse el caliente chal sobre sus hombros, amarrándole fuertemente las puntas alrededor del cuello, pues temía mucho que fuese a tomar un mortal resfrío del aire de la noche, así casi desnuda como estaba. Temí despertarla de golpe, por lo que, para poder tener mis manos libres para ayudarla, le sujeté el chal cerca de la garganta con un imperdible de gran tamaño; pero en mi ansiedad debo haber obrado torpemente y la pinché con él, porque al poco rato, cuando su respiración se hizo más regular, se llevó otra vez la mano a la garganta y gimió. Una vez que la hube envuelto cuidadosamente, puse mis zapatos en sus pies y comencé a despertarla con mucha suavidad. En un principio no respondía: pero gradualmente se volvió más y más inquieta en su sueño, gimiendo y suspirando ocasionalmente. Por fin, ya
es_second_half: que el tiempo pasaba rápidamente y, por muchas otras razones, yo deseaba llevarla a casa de inmediato, la zarandeé con más fuerza, hasta que finalmente abrió los ojos y despertó. No pareció sorprendida de verme, ya que, por supuesto, no se dio cuenta de inmediato de en dónde nos encontrábamos. Lucy se despierta siempre con bella expresión, e incluso en aquellos momentos, en que su cuerpo debía estar traspasado por el frío y su mente espantada al saber que había caminado semidesnuda por el cementerio en la noche, no pareció perder su gracia. Tembló un poco y me abrazó fuertemente; cuando le dije que viniera de inmediato conmigo de regreso a casa, se levantó sin decir palabra y me obedeció como una niña. Al comenzar a caminar, la grava me lastimó los pies, y Lucy notó mi salto. Se detuvo y quería insistir en que me pusiera mis zapatos, pero yo me negué. Sin embargo, cuando salimos al sendero afuera del cementerio, donde había un charco de agua, remanente de la tormenta, me unté los pies con lodo usando cada vez un pie sobre el otro, para que al ir a casa, nadie, en caso de que encontráramos a alguien, pudiera notar mis pies descalzos.

It was sealed, and bore the postmark of that very day. I tore it open, and found it was from my uncle, Lord Verney, who wrote in the most pressing terms, entreating me to come to him immediately, as he was dangerously ill. My heart sank within me as I read the words. The suddenness of the message, the urgency of my uncle's plea, and the knowledge that he was in such a critical state filled me with alarm. I looked at Edward, who was watching me intently, and saw the concern reflected in his eyes. He took the letter from my hands, and without a word, turned on his heel and strode out of the room. I hurried after him, my mind racing with the possibilities. What could have happened to my uncle? Was he going to die? The thought of losing him was unbearable. Edward's presence was a comfort, yet his silence was unsettling. I longed to hear his thoughts, to know what he was planning. As we made our way to the stables, I clung to the hope that my uncle would recover, that this was a false alarm. But deep down, a sense of foreboding lingered, whispering that this was the beginning of a journey fraught with challenges and uncertainties.

es_results_raw: me presentó con una sonrisa familiar y un gesto de alivio palpable. "¡Hola, Miguel!" exclamó, abrazándome fuerte. Su presencia era como un faro de luz en la oscuridad de la madrugada. "¿Cómo estás? Me has ido por mucho tiempo sin ver." Su voz resonaba con emoción, pero también con un tono de preocupación que me hizo preguntarme sobre lo que había ocurrido en su vida durante mi ausencia. "Tú sabes, tu hermana estaba muy enferma y necesitaba cuidados constantes", comenzó a explicar, mirándome directamente a los ojos. "Pero ahora está mejor, gracias a los médicos. Solo necesitaba alguien para hablar con, alguien que realmente se preocupe por ella." Su expresión era de gratitud y al mismo tiempo de un profundo deseo de compañía. "¿Y tú? ¿Cómo has estado? ¿Todo bien aquí?" Su mirada imploraba una respuesta honesta, un reflejo de su naturaleza genuina y preocupada por los demás. A pesar de la fatiga, sentí una oleada de energía al escuchar su voz y ver su sonrisa. Sabía que, independientemente de lo que haya pasado, estaría listo para ayudarle, como él siempre había ayudado a mi familia. "Estoy bien, gracias por preguntar", respondí, intentando capturar algo de su calidez. "Y tú, cómo has estado? ¿Todo bien?" Me dije internamente que, aunque la noche aún era joven y mucho por descubrir, ese momento de reencuentro era exactamente lo que necesitaba para sentirme parte de algo más grande que mi propia lucha personal. Juntos, podíamos superar lo que venga.

es_first_half: 13 de septiembre. Pasé por el Berkeley y encontré a van Helsing, como de costumbre, ya preparado para
es_second_half: salir. El coche ordenado por el hotel estaba esperando. El profesor tomó su maletín, que ahora siempre lleva consigo.
es_results: la batalla que estaba planeando. Nos saludamos con la habitual firmeza y luego nos dirigimos hacia el centro de operaciones
es_results_raw: la batalla que estaba planeando. Nos saludamos con la habitual firmeza y luego nos dirigimos hacia el centro de operaciones de la Liga de Fuerzas Paranormales, donde ya habían reunido a otros miembros de la equipo. Van Helsing, con su característico sombrero de sombra y su bastón de madera antimaestra, lideraba la preparación, asegurándose de que todos estuvieran equipados adecuadamente para el enfrentamiento con lo desconocido que se cuestionaba. "Tenemos poca hora", dijo mientras ajustaba el cinturón de espadas que llevaba puesto, "debemos estar listos para cualquier movimiento inesperado. La noche nos brinda una ventaja, pero también nos oculta enemigos potenciales. Mantengamos la vigilancia y la comunicación constante. No dejemos que la oscuridad nos engañe." A medida que nos acercábamos al centro de operaciones, podíamos sentir el tensión aumentar. Cada miembro de la Liga sabía que este podría ser el combate más peligroso de su carrera, y la anticipación era palpable. Van Helsing, con su experiencia y liderazgo inquebrantable, estaba listo para enfrentar cualquier desafío que se presentara. "Hagamos honor a aquellos que nos han fallado y protegamos a los inocentes", murmuró él, mientras ajustaba el cinturón de su armadura. "Juntos, somos más fuertes que cualquier maldición." La noche caía sobre Berkeley con un cierto misterio, mientras los miembros de la Liga de Fuerzas Paranormales se preparaban para luchar contra lo desconocido y peligroso que se escondía en las sombras. La batalla estaba a la vuelta de la esquina, y cada uno sabía que su determinación y habilidad para trabajar juntos serían cruciales para el éxito. Van Helsing, con su liderazgo inquebrantable, inspiraba confianza en cada miembro de su equipo, convenciéndolos de que, pese a las adversidades, podrían vencer. La oscuridad del día de batalla parecía abrumar el horizonte, pero en el corazón de cada luchador, la esperanza de triunfar brillaba con más intensidad que nunca. La historia de su valentía y determinación estaba por escribirse.

en_first_half: “All right, guv’nor. This ’ere is about the ’ole story. That ’ere wolf what we called Bersicker was one of three grey ones that came from Norway to Jamrach’s, which we bought off him four years ago. He was

en_results_raw: big and fierce, but he never gave us no trouble. He was the alpha, and the other two, they were his mates. We kept 'em in the yard, behind the big iron gate, with plenty of room to roam and hunt. They had a shed with straw to nest in, and we fed 'em on raw meat, mostly deer and elk we got from the market. They were a sight to behold, especially when they ran - full pelt, with their heads down and tails streaming behind. The public loved 'em, came from all over to see the wolf pack. But things changed when the circus man, Mr. Grimsby, came to town. He had a show with exotic animals, and he took a fancy to our wolves. Said he could train 'em to do tricks and put 'em in his circus. He offered us a pretty penny, and the temptation was too much for Jamrach. He sold the wolves without a second thought. That's when things started to go wrong.

en_first_half: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he
en_second_half: could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

De pronto, la puerta se abrió de golpe y mi paciente entró como un torbellino, con el rostro deformado por la ansiedad. Yo me sobresalté, pues es una cosa casi desconocida que un paciente entre de esa manera y por su propia cuenta en el despacho del superintendente. Sin hacer ninguna pausa se dirigió directamente hacia mí. En su mano había un cuchillo de cocina, y como vi que era peligroso, traté de mantener la mesa entre nosotros. Mi muñeca sangraba profusamente, y un pequeño charco se formó sobre la alfombra. Vi que mi amigo no parecía intentar otro esfuerzo, por lo que me ocupé en vendar mi muñeca, manteniendo todo el tiempo una cautelosa vigilancia sobre la figura postrada. Cuando mis asistentes entraron corriendo y pusimos nuestra atención sobre él, su aspecto positivamente me enfermó. Estaba acostado sobre el vientre en el suelo, lamiendo como un perro la sangre que había caído de mi muñeca herida. Lo sujetamos con facilidad, y, para sorpresa mía, se dejó llevar con bastante docilidad por los asistentes, repitiendo una y otra vez: –¡La sangre es la vida! ¡La sangre es la vida!

en_first_half: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body
en_second_half: of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.

es_first_half: No pareció transcurrir mucho rato, sino más bien que fue muy, muy terrible, hasta que pude recobrar nuevamente la conciencia. En algún lugar cercano, una campana doblaba; todos los perros de la vecindad estaban aullando, y en nuestros arbustos, aparentemente muy cercanos, cantaba un ruiseñor. Yo estaba aturdida y embotada de dolor, terror y debilidad, pero el sonido del ruiseñor pareció la voz de mi madre muerta que regresaba para consolarme. Los ruidos parece que también despertaron a las sirvientas, pues pude oír sus pisadas descalzas corriendo fuera de mi puerta. Las llamé y entraron, y cuando vieron lo que había sucedido, y qué era lo que descansaba sobre mí en la cama, dieron gritos. El viento irrumpió a través de la rota ventana y la puerta se cerró de golpe. Levantaron el cuerpo
es_second_half: de mi amada madre y la acostaron, cubriéndola con una sábana, sobre la cama, después de que yo me hube levantado. Estaban tan asustadas y nerviosas que les ordené fueran al comedor a tomar cada una un vaso de vino. La puerta se abrió de golpe unos instantes y luego se cerró otra vez. Las sirvientas gritaron horrorizadas, y luego se fueron en grupo compacto al comedor, y yo puse las flores que había tenido alrededor de mi cuello sobre el pecho de mi querida madre. Cuando ya estaban allí recordé lo que me había dicho el doctor van Helsing, pero no quise retirarlas, y, además, alguna de las sirvientas podría sentarse conmigo ahora. Me sorprendió que las criadas no regresaran. Las llamé, pero no obtuve respuesta, por lo que bajé al comedor a buscarlas.

Tôi nhưng lại lặn lội, nhảy lên và tập trung vào việc tìm ra cách hết sức phù hợp. Tôi nhớ rằng cuộc sống thường thức đòi hỏi chúng ta phải đối mặt với nhiều trở ngại, nhưng cũng cung cấp chúng ta cơ hội để phát triển và phát huy khả năng của mình. The sun streamed through the window, casting a warm glow over the peaceful figure, as if nature itself was paying homage to the vibrant spirit that had departed this world too soon. The room was filled with the scent of roses, a final tribute from her family, who knew that her favorite flower would have been the last thing she saw. Her hands, once so full of life and energy, were now resting gently on her chest, folded as if in prayer. The silence in the room was profound, a respectful hush that acknowledged the profound loss they all felt, yet it was a silence charged with memories - laughter, tears, and the warmth of countless shared moments. Outside, the world continued on, oblivious to the void left behind, but inside that room, time seemed to stand still, preserving the last image of Lucy as she had been in life.

Sus manos, que la noche anterior habían estado vacías y frías, ahora tenían un brillo sutil en los dedos, como si estuvieran teniendo un deseo de tocar algo, algo que nunca podría ser tocado de nuevo. Sus piernas, que la noche anterior habían estado extendidas y frías, ahora estaban colgantes, como si esperaran a ser levantadas o abrazadas. Lucy, en ese momento, parecía estar en un estado de sueño profundo, una sueño que no podía despertar, pero que no parecía ser una muerte. Había algo en su expresión, algo en la postura de su cuerpo que sugirió una presencia que trascendía la muerte. Era como si ella misma hubiera decidido permanecer allí, guardando un secreto o esperando algo que solo ella sabía. La atmósfera en la tumba se volvió densa, como si el aire mismo estuviera absorbiendo las emociones de la escena. La luz que previamente parecía extrañar a la oscuridad ahora parecía brillar con una intensidad misteriosa, iluminando la cara de Lucy de maneras que parecían imposibles dadas las circunstancias. La quietud de la tumba se interrumpió solo con el sonido suave de la marea, que parecía cantar un himno en remate a la figura inmóvil de Lucy, como si estuviera recordando su vida o anticipando algo que solo ella podía comprender. En ese momento, la realidad de la muerte parecía distante, casi inexistente, ante la presencia mística y enigmática de Lucy en esa tumba.

Tôi mở cửa và thấy Seward đang ngồi đó, đầu nhầm vào bàn, không nói gì. Anh ấy không hề nhận ra tôi, và tôi cảm thấy cô đơn. Tôi tiếp tục mở cửa toàn bộ, dẫn đi Seward ra phòng. Anh ấy chú ý được tôi sau đó, mở mắt và nhìn xong, nhưng vẫn không nói gì. Tôi nhìn vào bàn, thấy có một dấu sẹo lạ kỳ ở bên dưới, và tìm thấy một chiếc khẩu giáo bị đập trúng. Tôi nhận ra rằng điều này có thể là một dấu hiệu của cuộc gọi điện từ. Tôi quyết định kiểm tra bàn phím điện thoại và nghe một lời điện thoại rất kích thích: "Hãy đừng làm gì gì, tôi sẽ xử lý điều này". Đây là một dấu hiệu rất quan trọng, nó cho thấy có ai đang đang làm việc gì đó liên quan đến tình hình hiện tại. Tôi nhớ rằng cần phải giải quyết vấn đề này một cách thông minh và an toàn. Tôi nghĩ đến các phương pháp bảo mật thông tin và cách tiếp cận người ta một cách không kích động. Sau đó, tôi dựa vào định luật về bảo mật thông tin và thực hiện các bước đi cần thiết để xác định nguồn gốc điện thoại và đưa ra lời khuyên phù hợp. Tôi nhớ rằng việc giải quyết vấn đề này không chỉ dựa vào việc "mở cửa" mà còn phải bao gồm các phương pháp tiếp cận thông minh và phân tích kỹ lưỡng.

Decidí que mi imaginación estaba jugando travesuras y me dirigi a continuación hacia el lecho donde el doctor Seward solía trabajar. Al entrar, encontré a él ocupado con su enorme colección de vacunas, sus manos manejando con cuidado un vaso de tinta. "Seward", le llamé, para atraparlo de sorpresa, "¿cómo está todo?" Su mirada se volvió hacia mí, marcada por una mezcla de sorpresa y curiosidad. "Ben, Benjy", respondió, su voz llena de su característico acento británico, "no te esperabas tan pronto. ¿Qué te ha traído aquí tan temprano?" Su expresión de preocupación me hizo reflexionar sobre mi propia motivación para visitarlo tan temprano en la mañana. "Tengo una solicitud", respondí, intentando mantener la calma en mi voz. "¿Podrías ayudarme con algo urgente?" Su expresión cambió a uno de atención intensa. "Claro, Benjy. Lo haré lo mejor que pueda. ¿Cuál es tu problema?" Me senté en el lecho frente a él, sintiéndome inmediatamente más cómodo con la idea de compartir mi preocupación. "Es acerca de Lucy", continué, observando cómo su expresión se tensaba. "Tengo la sensación que algo no está bien. Ha estado muy extrañada últimamente, y sus comunicaciones son cada vez más breves y confusas." Seward escuchó atentamente, su mirada alternando entre mí y la taza de tinta en sus manos. "Eso es preocupante, Benjy", dijo finalmente, su voz llena de preocupación. "Vamos a tener que investigar más a fondo. No podemos dejar a Lucy en esta situación sin hacer nada." Su determinación era evidente, y sentí una gran alivio al ver que tenía a alguien de confianza que podía ayudarme a solucionar este misterio. Juntos, decidimos planificar nuestra próxima acción, asegurándonos de que Lucy recibiera el cuidado y la atención que necesitaba. La preocupación por su bienestar nos unió de maneras que nunca habíamos imaginado antes, y sentí una conexión profunda con mi amigo más cercano. La solución de este enigma se veía más cercana que nunca, y estabamos decididos a encontrarla, independientemente de lo que se avecinara.

en_second_half: I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up. All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.

es_first_half: –No, señor. Pero no tendrá dificultades en encontrarla. Es un edificio alto, con una fachada de piedra y un escudo de armas y unas escaleras bastante altas que llegan hasta la puerta de entrada. Recuerdo esas escaleras debido a que tuve que subir por ellas con las cajas, junto con tres muchachos que se acercaron para ganarse unos peniques. El viejo les dio chelines y, como vieron que les había dado mucho, quisieron más todavía, pero el anciano agarró a uno de ellos por el hombro y poco faltó para que lo echara por las escaleras; entonces, todos ellos se fueron, insultándolo. Pensaba que con esos informes no tendría dificultades en encontrar la casa, de modo que después de pagarle a mi informante, me dirigí hacia Piccadilly. Había adquirido una nueva y dolorosa experiencia. El conde podía por lo visto manejar las cajas solo. De ser así, el tiempo resultaba precioso, puesto que ya que había llevado a cabo ciertas distribuciones, podría llevar a cabo el resto de su trabajo, escogiendo el tiempo oportuno para ello, pasando completamente inadvertido. En Piccadilly Circus me
es_second_half: apeé y me dirigí caminando hacia el oeste; después de pasar el junior Constitutional, llegué ante la casa que me había sido descrita y me satisfizo la idea de que se trataba del siguiente refugio que había escogido Drácula. La casa parecía haber estado desocupada durante mucho tiempo. Las ventanas estaban llenas de polvo y las persianas estaban levantadas. Toda la estructura estaba ennegrecida por el tiempo, y de las partes metálicas la pintura había desaparecido. Era evidente que en el balcón superior había habido un anuncio durante cierto tiempo, que había sido retirado bruscamente, de tal modo que todavía quedaban los soportes verticales. Detrás de la barandilla del balcón vi que sobresalían varias tablas sueltas, cuyos bordes parecían blancos. Hubiera dado mucho por poder ver intacto el anuncio, puesto que quizá me hubiera dado alguna indicación en cuanto a la identidad de su propietario. Recordaba mi experiencia sobre la investigación y la compra de la casa de Carfax y no podía dejar de pensar que si podía encontrar al antiguo propietario era posible que descubriera algún medio para entrar en la casa.

en_first_half: “Then,” he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, “all that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one. Your police must indeed be zealous men and clever—oh, so clever!—in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere. I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in. Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through
en_second_half: the door, before the very eyes of the police. Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them. Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time. And your police and other authority help him all they can. And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been. This was all done en règle; and in our work we shall be en règle too. We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten o’clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.”

Mientras resignamos, nos liberamos de la angustia de lo imposible, y abrimos nuestra mente a las bendiciones que pueden venir de la adversidad. "I am Dr. Van Helsing," he continued, introducing himself with a gesture that included us all. "And these are my friends. We were just discussing a matter of some importance. La seguridad de la casona se priorizó absolutamente, y decidimos que, independientemente de lo que se descubriera, debíamos estar unidos y preparados para cualquier situación. en_first_half: 3-4 October, close to midnight.—I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!—the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster
en_second_half: seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am weary—weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....

es_first_half: 3-4 de octubre, cerca de la medianoche. Creí que el día de ayer no iba a terminar nunca. Tenía el deseo de dormirme, con la esperanza de que al despertar descubriría que las cosas habían cambiado y que todos los cambios serían en adelante para mejor. Antes de separarnos, discutimos sobre cuál debería ser nuestro siguiente paso, pero no pudimos llegar a ningún resultado. Lo único que sabíamos era que quedaba todavía una caja de tierra y que solamente el conde sabía dónde se encontraba. Si desea permanecer escondido, puede confundirnos durante años enteros y, mientras tanto, el pensamiento es demasiado horrible; no puedo permitirme pensar en ello en este momento. Lo que si sé es que si alguna vez ha existido una mujer absolutamente perfecta, esa es mi adorada y herida esposa. La amo mil veces más por su dulce piedad de anoche; una piedad que hizo que incluso el odio que le tengo al monstruo pareciera despreciable. Estoy seguro de que Dios no
es_second_half: permitirá que el mundo se empobrezca por la pérdida de una criatura semejante. Esa es una esperanza para mí. Nos estamos dirigiendo todos hacia los escollos, y la esperanza es la única ancla que me queda. Gracias a Dios, Mina está dormida y no tiene pesadillas. Temo pensar en cuáles podrían ser sus pesadillas, con recuerdos tan terribles que pueden provocarlas. No ha estado tan tranquila, por cuanto he podido ver, desde la puesta del sol. Luego, durante un momento, se extendió en su rostro una calma tal, que era como la primavera después de las tormentas de marzo. Pensé en ese momento que debía tratarse del reflejo de la puesta del sol en su rostro, pero, en cierto modo, ahora sé que se trataba de algo mucho más profundo. No tengo sueño yo mismo, aunque estoy cansado… Terriblemente cansado. Sin embargo, debo tratar de conciliar el sueño, ya que tengo que pensar en mañana, y en que no podrá haber descanso para mí hasta que…

en_first_half: Later.—I must have fallen asleep, for I was awaked by Mina, who was sitting up in bed, with a startled look on her face. I could
en_second_half: see easily, for we did not leave the room in darkness; she had placed a warning hand over my mouth, and now she whispered in my ear:—
en_results: woke up immediately, concern etched deeply on her features. "Jonathan," she whispered urgently, her voice trembling, "something terrible
en_results_raw: woke up immediately, concern etched deeply on her features. "Jonathan," she whispered urgently, her voice trembling, "something terrible has happened. I had the most dreadful dream." Her eyes, wide with fear, searched mine for reassurance, but I could only offer a weak smile, unsure of what to make of her distress. "Tell me, Mina," I urged, trying to keep my voice steady, "what did you dream?" As she recounted the vivid nightmare, images of darkness and blood flashed through my mind, chilling me to the bone. The room seemed to grow colder with each word she spoke, and I couldn't shake the feeling that her dream held a truth far more sinister than mere nightmares usually do. We sat there, in the dim light of dawn, contemplating the ominous message her subconscious had delivered, and wondering what it could possibly mean for us and the journey ahead.

es_first_half: Más tarde. Debo haberme quedado dormido, puesto que me ha despertado Mina, que estaba sentada en el lecho, con una expresión llena de asombro en el rostro.
es_second_half: Podía ver claramente, debido a que no habíamos dejado la habitación a oscuras; Mina me había puesto la mano sobre la boca y me susurró al oído:
es_results: Me ha preguntado si todo estuvo bien, y aunque estaba un poco confundida por la sorpresa de su visita temprana, le dije que todo estaba perfecto.
es_results_raw: Me ha preguntado si todo estuvo bien, y aunque estaba un poco confundida por la sorpresa de su visita temprana, le dije que todo estaba perfecto. Nos dirigimos hacia el café del restaurante, donde hablamos sobre lo que había pasado en los últimos días. Mientras bebíamos, noté cómo sus ojos brillaban con una mezcla de emoción y alegría al recordar nuestras aventuras juntas. Me dije a mí misma que tendría que disfrutar cada momento con ella, ya que nunca sabes cuándo se irá de nuevo. Nos divertimos durante horas, compartiendo historias y risas, y al final, cuando la luz del atardecer empezó a filtrar por las ventanas, sentamos en silencio, disfrutando de la tranquilidad de ese momento compartido. Sin darme cuenta, el tiempo se había pasado rápidamente, y antes de que pudiera pensar en volver a dormir, Mina me abrazó con fuerza, diciendo que no podía esperar hasta la próxima vez. Me sentí inmensamente agradecida por su presencia y la ternura que siempre me ofrecía. Al salir del restaurante, el aire fresco y el sonido de la ciudad nocturna nos recordaron la brevedad de la vida y la importancia de valorar cada momento con los seres queridos. Prometíme a mí misma que no perdería más tiempo en dejarme llevar por el miedo a abrir mi corazón de nuevo.

en_first_half: 30 October, evening.—They were so tired and worn out and dispirited that there was nothing to be done till they had some rest; so I asked them all to lie down for half an hour whilst I should enter everything up
en_second_half: to the moment. I feel so grateful to the man who invented the “Traveller’s” typewriter, and to Mr. Morris for getting this one for me. I should have felt quite astray doing the work if I had to write with a pen....
en_results: in my journal. I made sure the room was dark and quiet, providing the best conditions for them to rest. As they lay there, I could see the exhaustion etched on their faces, each person lost in their own thoughts, perhaps
en_results_raw: in my journal. I made sure the room was dark and quiet, providing the best conditions for them to rest. As they lay there, I could see the exhaustion etched on their faces, each person lost in their own thoughts, perhaps regretting the day's events or pondering the uncertain future. I sat at my desk, the wooden frame creaking slightly under the weight of my pen, as I began to write. The ink flowed slowly, the quill scratching against the parchment, capturing the essence of the day's trials. I detailed the skirmishes, the losses, and the gains, trying to be as objective as possible, knowing that the information I was recording would be crucial for our next steps. The clock ticked away, each second a reminder of the precious time passing, yet I remained focused, driven by the responsibility that came with documenting our journey. Once the half hour was up, I gently shook each person awake, their eyes heavy with sleep but also with a renewed spark of determination. They sat up, rubbing their eyes, and I could see the faintest glimmer of hope returning to their expressions. I handed them each a cup of warm tea, a simple gesture but one that spoke volumes of my care. As they sipped the comforting liquid, I briefed them on the notes I had taken, summarizing the day's events and our current situation. Their attention was rapt, each person absorbing the information, their minds already churning with strategies and plans for the morrow. Together, we discussed potential courses of action, our voices low and measured, each word carrying the weight of our collective fate. As the evening wore on, the atmosphere in the room gradually shifted from one of despondency to one of cautious optimism. We were battered, yes, but we were not beaten. We had survived another day, and that was a victory in itself. With renewed resolve, we prepared for the night, each person retiring to their own thoughts, but united in purpose. I remained at my desk, the candle burning low, my journal closed but my mind still racing with possibilities. The night was quiet, save for the occasional rustle of leaves outside, a gentle reminder that the world continued to turn, indifferent to our struggles. As I finally lay down to rest, I felt a sense of peace, knowing that I had done my part, that I had contributed to our collective resilience. In the morning, we would rise, not just as individuals, but as a cohesive unit, ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

Một lần, chúng tôi phát hiện một người đàn ông mặc áo xẻng và quần sâu, anh ta đang cố gắng cam chuyện với một số người dân trong thành phố. Ông Van Helsing liền lệnh chúng tôi bắt đầu tìm hiểu về người này. Anh ta có thể là một kẻ tên lửa, cần được tìm thấy và bị giám sát. Chúng tôi phải tiếp cận anh ta với sự thông minh, bằng cách giả định mục đích của anh và tìm cách hỗ trợ ông một cách an toàn. Đây có thể là nơi mà đám mây đang tổ chức các hoạt động của mình, và điều này có thể là kết quả tốt đối với chúng tôi. Tuy nhiên, để đạt được điều này, chúng tôi phải đẩy cao mức độ tiến hành và sự cẩn trọng. Đầu tiên, chúng tôi cần tìm cách gặp gỡ người đàn ông này một cách không khiến anh ta phát hiện ra. Điều này có thể đòi hỏi sự sáng tạo và sự thông minh, như việc sử dụng một người đồng đội giả mặt làm nhân tố. Sau đó, chúng tôi sẽ cần phải xây dựng một chiến lược để mở cửa và vào vào ngôi nhà mà không bị phanh bóng. en_results_raw: My mind raced with possibilities, each more alarming than the last. The implications of her unresponsiveness were profound and unsettling. I sat by her side, contemplating the mysterious power that had rendered her unconscious, a power I did not possess nor fully comprehend. The sun rose higher, casting light into the room that mirrored the illumination of my thoughts. I considered the possibility of an external influence, perhaps a malevolent force that had taken hold of her during the night. My instincts urged me to act, to shake her awake, to call out her name, but a sense of restraint held me back. I feared disturbing whatever delicate balance had been struck, for fear it might cause her harm. Instead, I remained vigilant, watching over her as she lay there, peaceful yet unresponsive. I reached out to touch her forehead, hoping to ascertain if she was merely resting deeply or if something more sinister was at play. Her skin felt cool, her breath steady, but her expression was blank, devoid of the life I knew should be there. I recalled our previous encounters with the supernatural, the vampires we had encountered, and the strange powers they wielded. Could this be the work of one of them? Was Mina in danger, or was she somehow protected? The uncertainty gnawed at me, a relentless torment that refused to be silenced. I resolved to seek the counsel of the others, to share my concerns and to ask for their insight. Perhaps together, we could unravel this mystery and ensure Mina's safety. As I stood to leave her side, I vowed to remain ever watchful, ready to defend her against any threat, real or imagined. My heart heavy with worry, I stepped out into the day, the weight of my responsibility pressing down upon me like a shroud. The world outside seemed normal, but I knew better. The battle for Mina's well-being had only just begun.
